key_points: Hurricane Ida is expected to make landfall on the US Gulf Coast as a Category 4 storm on Sunday, bringing heavy rain, tidal surge, and winds up to 225kmph.
The National Hurricane Center warns it could cause "life-threatening storm surge, potentially catastrophic wind damage, and flooding rainfall" starting Sunday morning.
Evacuation orders, both voluntary and mandatory, have been issued across the region, including in New Orleans.
Traffic out of New Orleans was heavy on Saturday, and most filling stations were out of petrol.
Louisiana Governor John Bel Edwards warned that Ida is a dangerous storm and preparation time is rapidly closing.
Residents in affected areas are taking precautions, with some choosing to stay and prepare rather than evacuate.
The storm is expected to hit on the same date Hurricane Katrina did 16 years ago, but Ida is forecasted to be more severe.
Ida's path through the industrial corridor between New Orleans and Baton Rouge is particularly concerning due to the concentration of critical infrastructure there.
US President Joe Biden held a conference call with governors and emergency response officials to prepare for Ida's landfall.
500 federal emergency response workers are in Texas and Louisiana to respond to the storm, with plans to restore power as soon as possible.
spokespersons: Jamie Rhome (Acting Deputy Director, National Hurricane Center)
